metadata.title: Enhanced adsorption of the cationic dyes in the spherical CuO/meso-silica nano composite and impact of solution chemistry

sections.text:
Accepted Manuscript
Editor's Choice Enhanced adsorption of the cationic dyes in the spherical CuO/meso-silica nano composite and impact of solution chemistry Zhijie Liang, Zhiwei Zhao, Tianyi Sun, Wenxin Shi, Fuyi Cui PII: S0021-9797(16)30683-X DOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jcis.2016.09.028 Reference: YJCIS 21580 To appear in: Journal of Colloid and Interface Science Received Date: 2 July 2016 Revised Date: 4 September 2016 Accepted Date: 13 September 2016
Please cite this article as: Z. Liang, Z. Zhao, T. Sun, W. Shi, F. Cui, Enhanced adsorption of the cationic dyes in the spherical CuO/meso-silica nano composite and impact of solution chemistry, Journal of Colloid and Interface Science (2016), doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jcis.2016.09.028
This is a PDF file of an unedited manuscript that has been accepted for publication. As a service to our customers we are providing this early version of the manuscript. The manuscript will undergo copyediting, typesetting, and review of the resulting proof before it is published in its final form. Please note that during the production process errors may be discovered which could affect the content, and all legal disclaimers that apply to the journal pertain.
Enhanced adsorption of the cationic dyes in the spherical
CuO/meso-silica nano composite and impact of solution chemistry
Zhijie Liang, a Zhiwei Zhao, *, b Tianyi Sun, a Wenxin Shi, * , a Fuyi Cui a
a State Key Laboratory of Urban Water Resource and Environment, School of Municipal and Environmental Engineering, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin 150090, China. b Department of National Defense Architecture Planning and Environmental Engineering, Logistical Engineering University, Chongqing 401311, China.
* Corresponding authors: Zhiwei Zhao, Tel. +86 023 86731057, E-mail: hit_zzw@163.com. Wenxin Shi, Tel. +86 0451 86284924, E-mail: SWX@hit.edu.cn;
Abstract: In this study, the spherical mesoporous silica (meso-silica MCM-41) and that inorganically modified with CuO (CuO/MCM-41 nano composite) were synthesized and characterized. It was demonstrated that CuO were successfully loaded in the synthesized nano composite CuO/MCM-41. Importantly, the loaded CuO had a significant enhancement effect on the adsorption of Crystal violet and Methylene blue. Adsorption kinetic of the tested cationic dyes in the synthesized materials fitted the pseudo-second-order kinetic model and Weber’s intra-particle diffusion model well. According to the Langmuir isotherm model, the maximum adsorption capacities (Qmax) of the CuO/MCM-41 towards Crystal violet and Methylene blue increased to 52.9 and 87.8 mg/g, while those of the pure MCM-41 were 46.2 and 65.7 mg/g, respectively. Due to the surface charge of CuO and the protonation of the dye molecules, the electrostatic forces between the loaded CuO and the organic cationic dyes contributed to the enhancement effect. Additionally, the presented results indicated that the adsorption of the cationic dyes in the CuO/MCM-41 depended on pH and ion strength of the solution but insignificantly on the coexisted humic acid due to the mesoporous character of CuO/MCM-41 nano composite. Keywords: meso-silica materials; inorganic modification; cationic dye; adsorption; solution chemistry

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Up to now, more than 100,000 kinds of commercial dyes are used with an annual production over 9 million tonnes [1]. Dyes are basic chemicals and widely used in many industries, including the textile, food processing, plastics, cosmetics, printing and dye manufacturing industries etc. [2]. Discharge of the highly colored wastewater from these industries gives undesirable color to the waters and toxicity to the aquatic life [3, 4]. Especially, many kinds of dyes can derive toxic byproducts in the process of oxidation, hydrolysis, or other chemical reactions in the waters [5]. Hence, treatment of the dye-contained wastewater have attracted serious concerns from researchers all over the world. To reduce the release of the synthetic dyes to the environment, various techniques, including adsorption, oxidation, and bio-degradation etc., have been developed for the removal of dyes in water [6 , 7 , 8 ]. Considering the eco-friendly application, adsorption technology is regarded as one of the most promising techniques without chemical consumption and flexibility to high concentration stress [9]. Sequentially, many kinds of adsorbents have been developed, such as carbon materials [10], meso-silica materials [11], bio-waste [12], and clay [13]. In the past several decades, the meso-silica materials are of great research interest in the area of the dye adsorption, due to the mesoporous structure and the functionalization possibility [14]. Huang et al. [5] reported that the meso-silica SBA-15 exhibited an excellent adsorption capability towards the cationic dye but almost no adsorption towards anionic and neutral dyes, and the Langmuir model and
pseudo-second-order kinetic model were well-fitted in the simulation of the adsorption behavior of the cationic dyes. Furthermore, recent studies have focused on the organically surface functionalization of the meso-silica materials to enhance the adsorption capacity towards dye pollutants [2, 15, 16]. Tsai et al. [17] reported that functionalization of meso-silica SBA-16 with carboxylic acid groups achieved an enhancement effect on the removal of the cationic dyes under basic conditions. However, some drawbacks still exist in the organic surface modification of the meso-silica materials, such as the complicated modification routes and strict conditions [18]. Hence, purpose of this study was to investigate whether the simply inorganic modification can overcome these drawbacks and enhance the adsorption capacity of the meso-silica materials towards dye pollutants. Based on the synthesis and characterization of the meso-silica MCM-41 and that inorganically modified with CuO (CuO/MCM-41 nano composite), effects of the loaded CuO on the adsorption of the typical cationic dyes (Crystal violet and Methylene blue) in the synthesized materials were evaluated in this study. Additionally, the impact of the solution chemistry on the removal of the cationic dyes by the CuO/MCM-41 was evaluated for further application.

sections.heading: 2.1 Synthesis of the meso-silica materials
sections.text:
The cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTMAB), tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS), and CuCl2·2H2O were all analytical grade (purity>99%) and purchased from Kelong Chemical Co., Ltd. (Chengdu, China).
Firstly, the template-contained meso-silica MCM-41 were synthesized via sol-gel method, and the synthesis procedure was similar to our previous report[19]. 6 g CTMAB, 250 mL ethanol, and 80 mL aqueous ammonia solution (13 M) were sequentially dissolved into 800 mL deionized water at room temperature 25 °C. 10 mL TEOS was poured in and efficiently stirred for 20 min. After aged for 12 h at 25 °C, the white solid was harvested by filtration and washed with deionized water to neutral pH, and then dried at 70 °C. After grinded into powder (100 mesh), the template-contained meso-silica material was attained, and it was defined as C16-MCM-41. The CuO-loaded MCM-41 was synthesized via the method of impregnation. 4 g C16-MCM-41 was added into 3.0 L copper solution (30 mg Cu 2+ /L, pH 7.0, prepared with CuCl2·2H2O and deionized water). After stirred for 2 h at 25 °C, the mixture was filtrated and washed with 3.0 L deionized water twice. The achieved sample was dried at 70 °C. After calcined at 560 °C for 5 h under air condition, the retained templates were completely removed, and CuO were formed in MCM-41. The achieved material was defined as CuO/MCM-41. The pure MCM-41 was achieved by calcination of C16-MCM-41, which were used as control. Both the CuO/MCM-41 and pure MCM-41 were grinded into powder (100 mesh).

sections.heading: 2.2 Characterization of the meso-silica materials
sections.text:
The crystalline phases of the prepared materials were detected on an X-ray diffractometer (XRD-6100, Shimadzu, Japan), and the low angle (2 - 8°) and high
angle (20 - 60°) spectrums were recorded at 2°/min under the condition of 40 kV and 30 mA with a Cu/Kα radiation. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) specific surface area and pore volume were calculated according to the N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms measured using an automated nitrogen adsorption analyzer (ASAP 2020, Micromeritics, America) at -196 °C. The surface morphologies of the prepared materials were observed with scanning-electron microscope (FEG-SEM Nova 400, FEI, US), and the energy dispersive X-ray spectrums (EDX) were recorded with an EDAX energy dispersive X-ray spectrometer (Genesis Apex 4). Additionally, after mixed with KBr powder and pressed into a tablet, the Fourier Transform Infrared spectrums (FT-IR) of the adsorbents before and after adsorption were obtained using a FT-IR spectrometer (6700, Nicolet, USA) from 32 scans in the wavenumber range of 400 - 2000 cm -1 .

sections.heading: 2.3 Adsorption experiment setup
sections.text:
Crystal violet and Methylene blue were selected as the representative of the cationic dyes, which were both analytical grade (purity>99%) and purchased from Kemiou Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (Tianjin, China). Information about Crystal violet and Methylene blue is shown in Table S1 (Supplementary Material). Stock solutions of Crystal violet and Methylene blue (1.8 g/L) were prepared with deionized water. Adsorption kinetics of Crystal violet and Methylene blue were carried out with batch experiments, separately. 0.02 g adsorbent was added into 38 mL deionized water in 50 mL brown glass tubes with Teflon sealed caps, and certain volumes of the dye stock solutions were added to give initial concentrations of Crystal violet 27 mg/L and
Methylene blue 36 mg/L. The pH was adjusted to 7.0±0.1 with NaOH (0.01 M) or HCl (0.01 M). The final volumes of the solutions were adjusted to 40 mL with deionized water, and the tubes were shaken in an air bathed shaker (SHZ-82, Jintan, China) at 150 r/min and 25 °C. Samples were taken timely and filtrated with 0.45 μm membranes (no targeted pollutants adsorption). The residual Crystal violet and Methylene blue were detected with a UV-vis spectrophotometer (Shimadzu UV-2450/2550, Japan) at 590 or 660 nm, and the concentrations were calculated according to the standard curves established. Additionally, the adsorbents were collected by centrifugation at the end of the tests and washed twice with 40 mL deionized water. The collected adsorbents were dried at 75°C for FT-IR detection. Followed the same procedure above, a series of initial concentrations of Crystal violet and Methylene blue were settled from 0 to 36 mg/L and from 0 to 45 mg/L, respectively. According to the detected residual concentration at adsorption equilibriums, the adsorption isotherms were established, and the Langmuir model was applied to the isotherms data. Additionally, one-factor experiments were carried out to evaluate the effects of pH, ion strength, and humic acid on the removal of Crystal violet (27 mg/L) and Methylene blue (36 mg/L) with the CuO/MCM-41. For the pH effect evaluation, a series of pH were adjusted initially with NaOH (0.01 M) or HCl (0.01 M). Similarly, the ion strength was settled from 0.01 to 0.12 M NaCl, and the humic acid concentration was settled from 5 to 40 mg/L. Samples were taken after the adsorption equilibrium and concentrations of the residual dyes were detected, and removal
efficiency was calculated.

sections.heading: 2.4 Data analysis
sections.text:
Derived from the original model (Equation I), the pseudo-second-order kinetic model (Equation II) was applied to explore the adsorption mechanism [20]. The Weber’s intra-particle diffusion model (Equation III) was applied to identify the steps involved in the adsorption process [21]. The parameters qt and qe are the adsorption amount at time t and the theoretical adsorption amount at equilibrium, and k2 is the adsorption rate constant of the pseudo-second-order model (g/(mg · min)). The constant kip (mg/(g · min 1/2 ) and h are those associated with the intra-particle diffusion rate and the thickness of the boundary layer at the each adsorption stage.
dqt/dt = k2·(qe - qt) 2 (I) qt = k2·qe 2 ·t/(1+ k2·qe·t) (II) qt = kip·t 1/2 + h (III)
The Langmuir model (Equation IV) was applied to the isotherms of Crystal violet and Methylene blue [22], and the removal efficiencies (η) were calculated based on mass balance (Equation V). The parameters Qmax and Qe are the theoretical maximum adsorption capacity and the tested equilibrium adsorption capacity. C0 and Ce are the initial concentration and the equilibrium concentration of dyes. Parameter b is the Langmuir constant.
Qe = b·Qmax·Ce/(1+b·Ce) (IV) η =100·(C0-Ce)/C0 (V)
All the simulations for the kinetic and equilibrium models were conducted with
Origin 8.0 to estimate the model parameters. Additionally, the Small-Sample Corrected Akaike Information Criterion (AICc) was calculated according to the Equation VI [23], and the Average Relative Error (ARE) was calculated according to the Equation VII [24].
AICc = n·Ln(RSS/n)+2p+2p·(p+1)/(n-p-1) (VI) ARE =100/n· (VII)
The n and p are the numbers of the data points and the model parameters, and RSS is the residual sum of squares gotten from the model simulations. The parameters qe, exp and qe, calc are the tested and calculated adsorption amount (or capacity) in the adsorption kinetic (or isotherm), respectively.

sections.heading: 3.1.1 Textural analysis of the meso-silica materials
sections.text:
The textural properties of the synthesized meso-silica materials are characterized by the X-ray diffraction and N2 adsorption/desorption techniques, and the results are shown in Fig. 1 and Table 1. As shown in Fig. 1, the low angle XRD spectrum of the synthesized meso-silica materials exhibits typical diffraction patterns of the mesoporous structure, and the diffraction peaks assigned to (100), (110), (200), and (210) planes. This results indicated that the synthesized materials are typical highly ordered MCM-41 with the 2D hexagonal array [25]. The wide-angle XRD spectrum (inner figure in Fig. 1) of the synthesized CuO/MCM-41 exhibited the major diffraction peaks at 35.6° and 38.8°,
which indexed as (111-002) and (111-200) planes of CuO, respectively. This is the typical characteristic for the phase of CuO crystallites, which is monoclinic with C2/c symmetry and four formula units per unit cell [26]. Considering the synthesis procedure of CuO/MCM-41, the formation of CuO may related to the complexation between the cupper cations and the templates retained in MCM-41 [27, 28]. The complexed copper cations were formed CuO after calcination and loaded in the pore channels of CuO/MCM-41.
To investigate the mesoporous structure of the synthesized materials, the inter-planar spacing (d) at (100) plane and center-to-center pore distance of the unit cell (a0) were calculated according to Equations V and VI [29], and the calculated results are listed in Table 1.
2d·sinθ=nλ (V) a0=2d100/(3) 1/2 (VI)
As shown in Table 1, the calculated textural parameters of XRD patterns are similar,
2θ
Fig. 1. XRD patterns of the synthesized pure MCM-41 and CuO/MCM-41.
which indicated that the MCM-41 structure was preserved though the CuO was loaded in CuO/MCM-41. All the above results confirmed that the MCM-41-based meso-silica materials were synthesized.
Table 1. Textural parameters of the synthesized pure MCM-41 and CuO/MCM-41.

MCM-41 3.28 3.79 1077.4 0.857 31.8 CuO/MCM-41 3.27 3.77 1165.8 0.943 32.4
*XRD patterns in low angle. *N2 adsorption/desorption measured at P/P0 = 0.97.
Additionally, the specific surface areas and pore structure parameters of the synthesized materials were calculated using the BET method based on the N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms, and the results are also listed in Table 1. Compared with the specific surface area of the pure MCM-41 (1077.4 m 2 /g), that of the CuO/MCM-41 increased to 1165.8 m 2 /g. Furthermore, the CuO/MCM-41 has average pore size and pore volume of 32.4 Å and 0.943 cm 3 /g, while those of the pure MCM-41 were 31.8 Å and 0.857 cm 3 /g. Similar results were reported with Ti-MCM-41 and Ni-MCM-41, which were attributed to the inner pores created by the modification [30, 31]. Hence, it is concluded that the pore structure of the synthesized materials is enhanced by the formation of new inner surface and pore created by the loaded CuO in the channels of CuO/MCM-41.

sections.heading: 3.1.2 SEM analysis of the meso-silica materials
sections.text:
To investigate the morphology and composition of the synthesized materials, Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscopy (FE-SEM) images and Energy Dispersive
X-ray (EDX) spectrums were obtained (Fig. 2).
As shown in Fig. 2A and 2B, both of the synthesized materials showed a spherical morphology, and the mean size was around 300 nm. This indicates that the morphology of MCM-41 was not changed by the loaded CuO. As demonstrated by the EDX spectrums (Inner figures), there is no Cu peak in the EDX spectrum of the pure MCM-41, but a Cu peak existed in the spectrum of CuO/MCM-41. Hence, we concluded the CuO nanoparticles were successfully loaded in CuO/MCM-41, which was in line with the XRD analysis results.

sections.heading: 3.2 Adsorption kinetics
sections.text:
The adsorption kinetics of Crystal violet and Methylene blue in the synthesized materials are shown in Fig. 3 (A and B).
A B
Fig. 2. Scanning electron micrographs and Energy dispersive X-ray spectrums (Inner figues) of the synthesized MCM-41 (A) and CuO/MCM-41 (B). Bar equals to 100 nm.
The adsorption amount of Crystal violet and Methylene blue increased rapidly in the first 20 min and then followed by a gradually increase from 20 min to 80 min with both the pure MCM-41 and CuO/MCM-41. To achieve the adequate equilibriums, the furhter experiments were conducted for 60 min. As shown in Table 2, the adsorption kinetics of the tested dyes fitted the Pseudo-second-order model well (R 2 > 0.98). Additionally, the adsorption amount of both Crystal violet and Methylene blue were 57.1 and 66.1 mg/g in CuO/MCM-41, which were much higher than those in the pure MCM-41 (37.4 and 43.6 mg/g). This indicated that the adsorption capacity of

CuO/MCM-41 towards the tested dyes was greatly enhanced by the loaded CuO. Interestingly, the adsorption rate of Crystal violet was significantly decreased from 0.0266 to 0.0141 g/(mg•min) with CuO doped in MCM-41. According to the regression of the Weber’s intra-particle diffusion model based on Fig. 3C and 3D, adsorption process of Crystal violet was divide into three steps: external diffusion (k1p), intra-particle diffusion (k2p), and adsorption caption (k3p) [32]. According to the regression data shown in Table 2, it suggested that external diffusion and intra-particle diffusion of Crystal violet was higher in CuO/MCM-41 (21.06 and 4.43 mg/(g•min 1/2 )) than those in the pure MCM-41 (17.92 and 3.35 mg/(g•min 1/2 )). This was related to the enhanced pore structure of CuO/MCM-41, and similar phenomenon was observed in the adsorption of arsenate in the granular schwertmannite [33]. However, constant k3p for the adsorption caption stage was lower in CuO/MCM-41 (0.34 mg/(g•min 1/2 )) than that in the pure MCM-41 (0.82 mg/(g•min 1/2 )). Hence, considering the decrease of the adsorption rate of Crystal violet in CuO/MCM-41, it was concluded that the rate-limiting step for Crystal violet adsorption in CuO/MCM-41 was the adsorption caption stage but not the external and intra-particle diffusion stages. Similarly, as for the adsorption of Methylene blue, the enhanced pore structure of CuO/MCM-41 induced a fast external diffusion(k1p in Table 2), and the adsorption caption stage limited the adsorption process (k3p in Table 2) in CuO/MCM-41. However, constant k2p for the intra-particle diffusion stage in CuO/MCM-41 (9.11 mg/(g•min 1/2 )) was lower than that in the pure MCM-41 (9.45 mg/(g•min 1/2 )), indicating that the intra-particle diffusion stage also limited the adsorption process of
Methylene blue in CuO/MCM-41. Hence, it resulted the adsorption rate of Methylene blue was insignificantly effected by the loaded CuO in CuO/MCM-41. The difference between the adsorption processes of Crystal violet and Methylene blue in CuO/MCM-41 may attribute to the intra-particle diffusion resistance caused by the size and shape of the dye molecule [32].

sections.heading: 3.3 Adsorption isotherm analysis
sections.text:
The adsorption isotherms of Crystal violet and Methylene blue in the synthesized materials are presented in Fig. 4.
As shown in Fig. 4, it reveals that the CuO/MCM-41 had a higher adsorption capacity towards both Crystal violet and Methylene blue than the pure MCM-41. To describe the adsorption capacity of the synthesized materials, the Langmuir model was applied to the isotherms of Crystal violet and Methylene blue, and the regression data is presented in Table 3. The maximum adsorption capacity (Qmax) of CuO/MCM-41 towards Crystal violet and Methylene blue were 52.9 and 87.8 mg/g, while those of

MCM-41 were 46.2 and 65.7 mg/g, respectively. This indicated that the loaded CuO significantly enhanced the adsorption capacities of CuO/MCM-41 towards both Crystal violet and Methylene blue.

MCM-41 65.7 1.18 0.77 0.05 0.9921 4.26 2.01 CuO/MCM-41 87.8 2.1 1.04 0.09 0.9858 2.09 3.70
SEa: Stander error of Qmax; SEb: Stander error of b; Adj.R 2: adjusted determination coefficient Additionally, the Langmuir constant b can quantitatively reflect the adsorption affinity of adsorbents towards the targeted pollutants. As shown in Table 3, values of b were 1.12 and 1.04 L/g for Crystal violet and Methylene blue in CuO/MCM-41, which were much higher than those in the pure MCM-41 (0.57 and 0.77 L/g). It indicated that the loaded CuO increased the adsorption affinity of CuO/MCM-41 towards both Crystal violet and Methylene blue. Firstly, the enhancement effect of the loaded CuO on dyes adsorption may relate to the higher specific surface area of CuO/MCM-41 (1165.8 m 2 /g), while it was 1077.4 m 2 /g for the pure MCM-41 (Table 1), which may increase the adsorption capacity towards the cationic dyes. Additionally, it reported that CuO banded on activated carbon surface could provide greater and more favorable reactive sites for dye molecular adsorption [34]. Hence, we concluded that the loaded CuO plays as “helper” for the adsorption of the cationic dyes by enhancing the pore structure of the synthesized materials and strengthening the interaction between the protonated dye
molecular and the CuO-loaded surface.

sections.heading: 3.4.1 pH
sections.text:
Effects of pH on the adsorptive removal of Crystal violet (27 mg/L) and Methylene blue (36 mg/L) by the CuO/MCM-41 are shown in Fig. 5A. As shown in Fig. 5A, both the removal efficiencies of Crystal violet and Methylene blue were strongly pH-dependent, and increased with the increase of pH. The removal efficiencies of Crystal violet at adsorption equilibrium sharply increased from 59.3% to 85.9% with the increase of pH from 4.3 to 9.1, and those of Methylene blue increased from 79.6% to 96.4% with a wide increase of pH from 4.1 to 9.3. Considering the enhancement mechanism of dye adsorption in CuO/MCM-41 (Section 3.3), the surface character of
Fig. 5. Effects of pH (A), ion strength (B), and coexisted Humic Acid (C) on the removal of Crystal violet (27 mg/L) and Methylene blue (36 mg/L) by the CuO/MCM-41. Adsorbent dosage was 0.02 g in 40 mL solution (60 min).
pH

the adsorbent and the existential form of the dye molecules were attributed to this pH-dependent result. Firstly, the pHpzc (pH point of zero charge) values determines the surface charge of the adsorbent [39]. As reported previously, the pHpzc values for the MCM-41 and CuO nanoparticles were about 4.5 and 5.5 [40, 41]. As we suggested that the CuO were loaded on the inner-channel surface of the MCM-41, the pHpzc of the CuO/MCM-41 were in the range of 4.5-5.5. At pH lower than the pHpzc value of the CuO/MCM-41, the competition from the H + ions for binding sites induced a decrease of the removal efficiency of the cationic dyes. At pH higher than the pHpzc value of the CuO/MCM-41, the surface of the adsorbent became negatively charged, which enhanced the removal of the cationic dyes by the electrostatic forces [42]. Similarly, Tian et al. [43] reported that adsorption of Crystal violet on the nano-Fe3O4 modified baker’s yeast increased in the pH range from 3 to 6 with the pHpzc at 4.7. On the contrary, since values of pKa are 0.8 and 5.6 for Crystal violet and Methylene blue (Table S1), the functional groups (such as amino group) of the dye molecular will be deprotonated with the pH increased [44, 45], which will lead to a decrease of dyes removal. Based on the presented results, increase of pH induced an enhancement on the interaction with the negatively charged surface of the CuO/MCM-41. Hence, it concluded that the surface character of the CuO/MCM-41 were dominant for the adsorption of the cationic Crystal violet and Methylene blue.

sections.heading: 3.4.2 Ion strength
sections.text:
Effects of ion strength on the removal of Crystal violet (27 mg/L) and Methylene blue
(36 mg/L) by the CuO/MCM-41 are shown in Fig. 5B. As shown in Fig. 5B, it indicated that the lower ion strength (<0.02 M NaCl) has significant enhancement effect on the removal of both Crystal violet and Methylene blue. However, when the ion strength was higher than 0.02 M NaCl, the removal efficiencies of the tested dyes increased insignificantly. It has been demonstrated that the concentration of various electrolytes in dye solution could change the removal of dye [46, 47]. Typically, the increase of salt concentration can screen the electrostatic interaction between the oppositely charged oxide surface and the dye molecules, resulting in a decrease of the cationic dye removal; meanwhile, the coexisted salt can also increase the dissociation of the dye molecules by facilitating the protonation and enhance the dyes removal [48]. Based on our results, the latter effect was dominant in the adsorption of both Crystal violet and Methylene blue. Hence, due to the increase of the dissociated dye ions, the removal of Crystal violet and Methylene blue increased with the increase of ion strength.

sections.heading: 3.4.3 Humic acid
sections.text:
To examine the effects of natural organic matters on the removal of the tested cationic dyes by CuO/MCM-41, humic acid at certain concentrations was added into the liquid phase of the adsorption vials. The results are shown in Fig. 5C. In fact, it is well know that humic acid are negatively charged in the pH range of 3.0-10.0, and the negative charged humic acid banded on the adsorbents subsequently improved the adsorption of the cationic dye. It was reported that the adsorbed humic acid significantly enhanced the adsorption of cationic dye RhB on the surface of
Fe3O4 nanoparticles [49]. However, the enhancement effect of the coexisted humic acid on the adsorption of the tested dyes was insignificantly as shown in Fig. 5C. This was reasonable due to the fact that the molecule size of humic acid is larger than the pore size of the mesoporous CuO/MCM-41 [50]. Hence, we conjectured that the coexisted humic acid was not adsorbed in the channels of CuO/MCM-41 in our study, which sequentially had insignificant effect on the removal of Crystal violet and Methylene blue.

sections.heading: 3.5 Adsorption mechanism of Crystal violet and Methylene blue in
sections.text:
CuO/MCM-41 To gain insight into the adsorption mechanism, the FT-IR spectrums of the CuO/MCM-41 before and after the adsorption of Crystal violet and Methylene blue were recorded, including those of the tested dyes (Fig. 6). As shown in Fig. 6, spectrum of the CuO/MCM-41 before adsorption shows the several absorption peaks at 1640, 1234-1087, 968, and 795-462 cm -1 , which were respectively caused by the deformation vibrations of adsorbed water molecules, the Si-O-Si stretching, the -OH bending, and the surface Si-O - groups bending vibrations [51]. After the adsorption of both Crystal violet and Methylene blue, the wavenumbers of the above absorption peaks do not shift to a higher or lower wavenumber, but the intensity of the Si-O-Si stretching peak at 1234 cm -1 significantly decreased. Due to the permanent negative charge of the Si-O-Si group, it is considered as a key role for the adsorption of both Crystal violet and Methylene blue by facilitating the electrostatic interaction towards the cationic dyes [52].
Importantly, it was reported that the negatively charged metal-oxide sites were also contributed to the adsorption of the positively charged organic molecules [53]. Hence, the CuO sites in the CuO/MCM-41 also plays an important role for the adsorption of the tested cationic dyes in the copper oxide modified MCM-41.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
The results of this study indicated that the inorganic modification with CuO had an enhancement effect on the adsorption of the cationic dyes in the meso-silica MCM-41. The enhanced adsorption of the tested cationic dyes related to the electrostatic forces between the loaded CuO and the organic cationic dyes with the help from the surface charge of CuO and the protonation of the dye molecules. The reported nano-composite CuO/MCM-41 shows high potential in dye-contained wastewater
Fig. 6. FT-IR spectrums of the dyes and CuO/MCM-41 (before and after adsorption). Initially, Crystal violet and Methylene blue were 27 mg/L and 36 mg/L, and adsorbent dosage was 0.02 g in 40 mL solution (pH=7.0, 80 min).

treatment, and the presented results indicates that the adsorption of the cationic dyes in the CuO loaded MCM-41 depended on pH and ion strength of the solution but insignificantly on the coexisted humic acid due to the mesoporous character of the CuO/MCM-41.
